newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan official to visit C. America - newspaper.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan official to visit C. America - newspaper.

text.p: Taiwan's top economic policy maker will visit seven Central American countries later in April to secure Taipei's formal ties with them amid increasing pressure from rival China, a local newspaper reported on Sunday.

The China Times said Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the cabinet's Council for Economic Planning and Development, planned to discuss Taiwan's trade relations with its allies in Central America -- which include Panama, Costa Rica and Nicaragua.
Offficials could not be reached for confirmation of the trip because of holiday.
The newspaper did not give details on Chiang's itinerary.

Taiwan says China has been trying to pressure the island's Central American allies to switch ties to Beijing since Panama invited Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui to attend an international conference on the future of the Panama Canal in September.
China has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province not entitled to international recognition since the two split after a civil war in 1949.

Taiwan, which is formally recognised by only 30 countries despite prosperous trade ties with many more, lost a major diplomatic battle to China in 1996 when South Africa announced it would switch formal ties to Beijing by the end of 1997.
